    A Graduate's Guide to Reading Structural Drawings

    Engr. Seun Adeyemi·2026-02-10

    Why Drawing Interpretation Matters


    Every construction project begins with drawings. Structural drawings are the language of the building site — they tell contractors what to build, how to build it, and to what specifications. An engineer who can't read drawings confidently is, frankly, not ready for site work.


    The Key Drawing Types


    ### General Arrangement (GA) Drawings

    These show the overall layout of the structure — column positions, beam spans, slab extents, and the relationship between structural elements. GA drawings are your roadmap.


    ### Reinforcement Detail Drawings

    These show the exact size, spacing, and placement of reinforcement bars in every structural element. Getting this wrong on site can compromise the entire structure.


    ### Section Drawings

    Cross-sections through beams, columns, slabs, and foundations showing internal dimensions, reinforcement layout, and cover requirements.


    ### Foundation Drawings

    Pad, strip, and raft foundation layouts with dimensions, reinforcement details, and formation level specifications.


    Common Mistakes Graduates Make


    1. Ignoring the drawing notes — Notes contain critical information about concrete grades, cover, lap lengths, and construction sequences

    2. Confusing scale — Always check the scale before measuring anything

    3. Not cross-referencing — Structural drawings must be read alongside architectural drawings to understand the full picture

    4. Assuming symmetry — Never assume one side mirrors the other unless the drawing explicitly states it


    How to Improve


  1. Study real project drawings (not just textbook examples)
  2. Visit active construction sites and compare what you see with the drawings
  3. Practice sketching structural details by hand
  4. Take ERA's AutoCAD & Civil Engineering Drawing course for intensive training

    5. At ERA


    Drawing interpretation is a core module in our flagship programme. Every participant works with real structural drawings from completed Nigerian projects, learning to read, interpret, and check them against site conditions.

    Empowering civil & mechanical engineering graduates for the building environment.
